body: @HrWangChengdu Because I created this pull request for you, the commit history now traces this to me. You can make a new PR with two commits where the first one removes every file you added in this PR and the second one adds them back in, so that the history will be traced to you.

Hi, I noticed that there is a new sym API [RNN](http://mxnet.readthedocs.io/en/latest/packages/python/symbol.html#mxnet.symbol.RNN), which seems to be utilizing the CuDNN v5 feature. 
Is this finished now? I found that there are two src files, rnn-inl.h and cudnn_rnn-inl.h. And in rnn-inl.h I saw a TODO mark.

And, will mask be supported in the RNN symbol? btw, any usage examples for this new symbol?
Thanks.
Actually I don't even have a machine with memory more than 70G. Running in cpu requires changes in workspace for convolution. Please see the documentation for this.
@piiswrong I have tried the latest one, and it is fixed.
@sbodenstein : Can you fix this operator for cudnn v5.0? the function parameters are different between 5.0 and 5.1.
@sxjscience The training speed is about 1 min for Cuda 7.5, while 10 min for 8.0. (Using mlp to train MNIST dataset.)

@Cdyzhao I'm using CUDA 8.0 + GTX 980 TI + Windows 10 and the training speed for CIFAR10 (`python train_cifar10.py`) is about 1120.45 samples/sec. Could you compare the speed of CUDA 7.5 and CUDA 8.0 on CIFAR10? MNIST is rather small and may not be suitable for benchmarking.

@Godricly: I tested this only for cudnn v5.0, and there wasn't a problem. Which parameters are different? And what is broken for 5.0? 

Also, I assumed they were the same, as the release notes of v5.1 state: "cuDNN 5.1 is fully API compatible with cuDNN 5.0."

@magic282: The cuDNN version is finished, but the TODO refers to adding a CPU version. There are also no examples yet.

Mask is not supported. How would you like the mask to work with this operator?

@sbodenstein Since I don't really know how to use the new symbol, I got no idea about the mask.
For now, the mask I implemented looks like this:

``` python
# stack LSTM
for i in range(self.num_of_layer):
    if i == 0:
        dp_ratio = 0.
    else:
        dp_ratio = self.dropout
    next_state = lstm(self.state_dim, indata=hidden,
                      prev_state=last_states[i],
                      param=param_cells[i],
                      seqidx=seq_idx, layeridx=i, dropout=dp_ratio)

    if self.use_masking:
        prev_state_h = last_states[i].h
        prev_state_c = last_states[i].c
        new_h = mx.sym.broadcast_mul(1.0 - mask, prev_state_h) + mx.sym.broadcast_mul(mask, next_state.h)
        new_c = mx.sym.broadcast_mul(1.0 - mask, prev_state_c) + mx.sym.broadcast_mul(mask, next_state.c)
        next_state = LSTMState(c=new_c, h=new_h)

    hidden = next_state.h
    last_states[i] = next_state
```
libcuda.so is under /usr/local/cuda/lib64/stubs/libcuda.so, just make a soft link to /usr/local/cuda/lib64/libcuda.so. I am not sure if this is a CUDA v7.0 problem.

@magic282: masking isn't directly supported by the cuDNN API yet, although variable length sequences are (others, such as the maintainer of the Torch RNN package has made comments about this: https://github.com/soumith/cudnn.torch/issues/210). 

There are two major masking approaches:
1) passing the mask info as an extra input tensor (like your example)
2) use zero-masking (or some other value), like Torch uses (eg. https://github.com/Element-Research/rnn#maskzeroninputdim) and Keras supports (see this discussion: https://github.com/fchollet/keras/issues/176).

I prefer the latter. We could make a feature request to NVIDIA regarding this.
I encounter similar issues before. Just compile your own version from source code, and the problem is solved.
@sbodenstein I think both of them are ok to me. BTW, have you tested the performance gain of CuDNN RNN using mxnet?

I also met AttributeError: 'module' object has no attribute 'WarpCTC'ï¼Œ and  solve itï¼š
uncomment the following linesï¼š
WARPCTC_PATH = $(HOME)/warp-ctc
MXNET_PLUGINS += plugin/warpctc/warpctc.mk
and reinstall the mxnet
copy the file:libwarpctc.so(warp-ctc/build) to usr/lib
then it will be ok

ok, batchnorm layer use different compute methods on mean and variance,
when do prediction, it only use a statistic of them.
so, at the begining, the output maybe clearly different, but with the model training done,
the difference will be very small.
Post your log and I'll likely be able to tell if it's normal or not
@zmonoid Hi, I just wonder why does shuffle the data has such big impact on training?

I'm getting the same error:

```
import numpy as np
import mxnet as mx
from PIL import Image

img = '2007_000480.jpg'
seg = img.replace("jpg", "png")
model_previx = "FCN8s_VGG16"
epoch = 19
ctx = mx.cpu()  #ctx = mx.gpu(0)

def get_data(img_path):
    """get the (1, 3, h, w) np.array data for the img_path"""
    mean = np.array([123.68, 116.779, 103.939])  # (R,G,B)
    img = Image.open(img_path)
    img = np.array(img, dtype=np.float32)
    reshaped_mean = mean.reshape(1, 1, 3)
    img = img - reshaped_mean
    img = np.swapaxes(img, 0, 2)
    img = np.swapaxes(img, 1, 2)
    img = np.expand_dims(img, axis=0)
    return img


fcnxs, fcnxs_args, fcnxs_auxs = mx.model.load_checkpoint(model_previx, epoch)
fcnxs_args["data"] = mx.nd.array(get_data(img), ctx)
data_shape = fcnxs_args["data"].shape
label_shape = (1, data_shape[2]*data_shape[3])
fcnxs_args["softmax_label"] = mx.nd.empty(label_shape, ctx)
exector = fcnxs.bind(ctx, fcnxs_args ,args_grad=None, grad_req="null", aux_states=fcnxs_args)
exector.forward(is_train=False)
output = exector.outputs[0]

```

So far, it works fine. This generates the error.

`output.asnumpy()`

Any ideas?  I'm using the model files supplied via a dropbox link by @tornadomeet: 
- FCN8s_VGG16-0019.params
- FCN8s_VGG16-symbol.json

@Weyne168 The file includes operations that calculate the value of two operands, e.g, a+b, a - b. Bitwise operations like XOR are not included currently. You need to implement these OPs.

@yitang Suppose you got the training samples like index [1...10] are labeled A,  index [11..20] labeled B, etc.

Your training batch size is 11. For the first batch the gradient moves towards regression on A (index 11 sample can be neglected as it contributes little to the loss in one batch), therefore for the next batch [12 ... 23] the network tends to classify all samples to A (result in the accuracy even lower than random guess), but will also drag the gradient towards the regression on B. Well... you would image what will happen next.

Bug report: 
mxnet.symbol.RNN dosn't work with mx.model.FeedForward, as in the mx model assume the first size in shape to be batchsize and will split it for multi-device training, while mxnet.symbol.RNN uses  Shape3(total_layers, batch_size, param_.state_size) for rnn init state input.
See exector_manager.py line 219

> data_shapes = {k: tuple([slices[i].stop-slices[i].start] + list(v[1:]))
>                            for k, v in train_data.provide_data + train_data.provide_label}

We should use Assign here to handle AddTo optimization correctly. @taoari Could you replace the line with Assign and get the plot again?
@pluskid @piiswrong
@luoruisichuan Yes, if pad = (3,3), it will add zeros outside each feature map by 3 circles.

@kikoqiu: this is not a bug, its a design decision. You can use SwapAxis to put it into [batch, seq length, in size] form. Otherwise, we could add support for [batch, seq len, in size] as a symbol option.
@taoari Yes, this should not be the cause.
@zmonoid  Thank you very much for your explanation! It's really helpful. I got the same problem when run VGG with small batch size (6).

W and b is not variables.
they are ndarray type.
mxnet can proceed fixed different size input.that means it can use a new size input which is different from the size of training.

@starimpact Thanks for your reply. But W & b are indeed `mx.Variable`s.
Current implementation only works when the `weight` and `bias` variables are generated by default, whose names would be `fc_weight` and `fc_bias` for the example case. But if we explicitly specify them and the name changes, it would be incorrect. You can simply verify that by printing `lr` in any optimizer.
